td.p: Thomson, John. Journal, Mackenzie River, 1800-1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0021

div.p: with 8 Men 4 Women & 2 children[.] There remains with Mr Wentzel 4 Men 1 Woman & 2 children – two of the former are to go in the Spring to Slave Lake in order to go out[.] [A] little before sun set arrived at the Forks & on the other side found an Indian along with his wife & 2 sons encamped there – put up our quarters along with him – he could not give us any news having passed the Summer he says all alone – he gave me the value of 4 Skins Beaver Meat &c. I really am very happy to have found this Indian for I am much afraid that we are going on a Wild Goose chace, as ten chances to one whether we see a single Indian along the way in order to show us the place appointed to Build a Fort, none of us have the least Idea of it. Piches is the only one that has seen the Spot but that is now of no avail as he is not here to shew it to us[.]

Sunday the 12th[.] Very cold foggy weather[.] [N]ot without a great deal of difficulty made our Host embark along with us, in order to shew us the place that the Rocky Mountain Indians wish to have their Fort[.] In the afternoon the weather grew Clear, & then (only) we had a full view of the Rocky Mountain – at whose smallness of height I was a little surprised, for to my eyes it does not appear to be such a Tremendous height as reported[.] A little before sun set we took 2 Men & one Woman in 3 Small Canoes going down the Current[.] Inquired of them concerning their Relations, but they could not give us any accounts of them – the only information that we could get from them was that they were all a great ways off (the Lord knows where)[.] These Indians are certainly a Most cursed Lying set of Rascals & there is not the least dependence to be put in a word of what they say – for they last spring promised that they
